column4: Ok let me explain what I am trying to do. I want to create an ip address on *this* machine - like 192.168.1.12 or 10.0.4.1 or whatever -- I want it to be so that anything sent to *that* ip address, on port 22 --- goes to a different ip address, on port 99 --- how can I do that?
in this way I can ssh to blah@10.0.4.1 instead of ssh to blah@_other_ip -p 99   -- removes the need to specify port
: You can tell etc/hosts an IP address and PORT ?
Is there a way to assign additional ips to this machine? If so I can modify ssh_config to use default ports
I'm sure squid would do it, although I don't know how easy it is to set up
yep got it - using alias + /etc/hosts -- got it working
how'd you do the alias part?
Just creating an internal ip visible to just this machine
then I can do whatever port forwarding I want on it
